classification.name: 1st Generation
spectrum_of_activity: limited Gram-negative coverage (e.g., some strains of E. coli, Klebsiella spp., P. mirabilis)

classification.name: 2nd Generation
spectrum_of_activity: generally less activity against Gram-positive cocci
cephamycins: activity against anaerobes, including Bacteroides spp.
may be active in vitro vs. ESBL-producing aerobic gram-negative bacilli but clinical efficacy data lacking

classification.name: 3rd Generation
spectrum_of_activity: parenteral agents have improved CNS penetration
all are subject to inactivation by ESBLs and AmpC beta-lactamases produced by Gram-negatives

classification.name: Advanced Generation
spectrum_of_activity: Cephalosporins with enhanced antibacterial spectrum against selected organisms
poor activity against Gram-negative anaerobes, Bacteroides spp. in particular

drugs.name: Cefepime
drugs.description: sometimes referred to as a 4th generation cephalosporin; activity against P. aeruginosa and AmpC-producing organisms; good CNS penetration

drugs.name: Ceftaroline fosamil acetate
drugs.description: activity against MRSA due to its affinity for binding PBP2a, the protein that mediates methicillin resistance

drugs.name: Ceftobiprole
drugs.description: activity against MRSA due to its affinity for binding PBP2a, the protein that mediates methicillin resistance

drugs.name: Ceftolozane-tazobactam
drugs.description: activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, ESBL producers, some AmpC producers

drugs.name: Ceftazidime-avibactam
drugs.description: same spectrum of activity as Ceftazidime plus activity against ESBL producers, AmpC producers, serine carbapenemase-producing Gram-negatives

drugs.name: Cefiderocol
drugs.description: activity against ESBL producers, AmpC producers, carbapenemase-producing Gram-negatives, including non-fermenters such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Acinetobacter spp. and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia; no activity against Gram-positive organisms or anaerobic organisms

adverse_effects: Increased risk of C. difficile toxin-mediated colitis with use of any cephalosporin, especially the 3rd generation drugs.
All beta-lactam antibiotics have potential for increasing risk of inducing or potentiating seizure activity.
